statement.p: What is the lead coefficient of a polynomial?

li.p: D) The coefficient of the highest power

solution.p: The coefficient of the highest power, that is, the coefficient of the largest degree

statement.p: Multiply (y + 2)(y^2 - 2y + 3)= .
What is the linear term of the product (x-3)(x+5) ?

solution.p: 2x is the linear term of x^2+2x-15\text{.}

statement.p: Find the coefficient of the fourth-degree term of the product of f(x) = 2x^6 + 2x^4 - x^3 + 5x^2 + 1 and g(x) = x^5 - 3x^4 + 2x^3 + x^2 - 4x - 2\text{.}
Answer:

solution.p: 2 is the coefficient of the x^4 term in the product.
To compute the fourth-degree term in the product, we multiply a term of f(x) of degree 4, 3, 2, or 0 by a term of g(x) of degree 0, 1, 2, or 4 respectively. We add those four products of terms:
So the fourth-degree term in the product is 2x^4\text{,} and the coefficient is 2\text{.}

An empty reflecting pool is 3 feet deep. It is 8 feet longer than it is wide, as illustrated above.

li.p: Write a polynomial function S(x) that gives the surface area of the empty pool.
Write a polynomial function V(x) for the volume of the pool.
We add the area of the bottom to the areas of each of the sides of the pool: S(x) = x^2 + 20x + 48
We multiply depth, length, and width: V(x) = 3x^2 + 24x

statement.p: Leon is flying his plane to Au Gres, Michigan. He maintains a constant altitude until he passes over a marker just outside the neighboring town of Omer, when he begins his descent for landing. During the descent, his altitude, in feet, is given by
where x is the number of miles Leon has traveled since passing over the marker in Omer.

li.p: What is Leons altitude when he begins his descent?
Use the Trace feature to discover how far from Omer Leon will travel before landing. (In other words, how far is Au Gres from Omer?)
Verify your answer to part (c) algebraically.
A(5) = 0\text{,} that is, Leon is on the ground (at altitude 0) when he is 5 miles past Omer.

webwork-reps.pg:
############################################# ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2024-04-08T17:15:41-07:00 ### A recent stable commit (2022-07-01): ### 6c761d3dba23af92cba35001c852aac04ae99a5f ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ############################################# ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(8.1.17) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", ); COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt');
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $a = Compute("8000"); $d = Compute("5"); $z = Compute("0");
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Leon is flying his plane to Au Gres, Michigan. He maintains a constant altitude until he passes over a marker just outside the neighboring town of Omer, when he begins his descent for landing. During the descent, his altitude, in feet, is given by
[```A(x) = 128x^3 - 960x^2 + 8000```]
where [`x`] is the number of miles Leon has traveled since passing over the marker in Omer.
a. What is Leon's altitude when he begins his descent?
[_]{$a}{4} ft
a. Graph [`A(x)`] in the window
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&} \begin{aligned} \text{Xmin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 5\\ \text{Ymin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 8000 \end{aligned} ```]
a. Use the _Trace_ feature to discover how far from Omer Leon will travel before landing. (In other words, how far is Au Gres from Omer?)
[_]{$d}{2} mi
a. Verify your answer to part (c) algebraically.
[`A(5)=`][_]{$z}{2}
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. 8000 ft
a. A graph is below.
a. 5 mi
a. [`A(5) = 0\text{,}`] that is, Leon is on the ground (at altitude 0) when he is 5 miles past Omer.
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p:
Explain why each calculation is incorrect.
\dfrac{x-6}{x-9} \rightarrow \dfrac{x-2}{x-3}
A) 3 is not a factor of numerator or denominator.
B) More cancelling is required.
\dfrac{2x+5}{2} \rightarrow x+5
A) 2 is not a factor of the numerator.
B) 2 should be subtracted from 5.

li.p: 3 is not a factor of numerator or denominator
2 is not a factor of the numerator

EarthCare decides to sell T-shirts to raise money. The company makes an initial investment of $100 to pay for the design of the T-shirt and to set up the printing process. After that, the T-shirts cost $5 each for labor and materials.
Express the average cost, C\text{,} per T-shirt as a function of the number of T-shirts EarthCare produces.
C=
Make a table of values for the function.
x 1 2 4 5 10 20
C
Graph the function and explain what it tells you about the cost of the T-shirts.

li.p: As the number of T-shirts increases, the average cost per shirt decreases, but eventually levels off and approaches $5 per T-shirt.

Express the teams time on the upstream leg as a function of the speed of the current.

solution.p: 50 mph

############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML The manager of a new health club kept track of the number of active members over the club's first few months of operation. The number, [`N`] of active members, in hundreds, [`t`] months after the club opened is given by the equation
[``` \begin{gathered} N=\dfrac{10t}{4+t^2} \end{gathered} ```]
a. Graph the equation in the window
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&} \begin{aligned} \text{Xmin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 9.4\\ \text{Ymin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 3 \end{aligned} ```]
a. Use the graph to find out in which months the club had 200 active members.
Months: [_]{$answer}{5} Enter month numbers separated by a comma.
a. Verify your answer algebraically by solving an equation.
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. A graph is below. a. 1, 4
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Solve the equation 4y^2 - x^2 = 16 when y = 1\text{.}
What does this tell you about the graph of the hyperbola?

li.p: The line y=1 is one of the asymptotes.
There are no points on the graph with y-coordinate 1.
The hyperbola opens left and right.

solution.p: There are no real solutions when y = 1\text{,} so there are no points on the graph with y-coordinate 1.

li.p: A hyperbola centered at the origin with vertices (0,1) and (0,-1) and asymptotes y=\dfrac{1}{3}x and y=\dfrac{-1}{3}x\text{.}
A parabola that opens upward from the vertex (1,-5)\text{.}
An ellipse centered at (-2,1) with a horizontal major axis, a=2 and b=\dfrac{2}{3} \text{.}

A
?
degenerate
central
translated
conic can be a point, a line, a pair of lines, or no graph at all.

The coefficients D\text{,} E\text{,} and F determine the
?
type
position
of the conic.

The graph is a
?
circle
ellipse
hyperbola
parabola
if one of A or C is zero.

If A = C (and B=0), the graph is a
?
circle
ellipse
hyperbola
parabola
.
A degenerate conic can be a point, a line, a pair of lines, or no graph at all.
The coefficients D\text{,} E\text{,} and F determine the position of the conic.
The graph is a parabola if one of A or C is zero.
If A = C (and B=0), the graph is a circle.

webwork-reps.pg:
############################################# ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2024-04-08T17:15:45-07:00 ### A recent stable commit (2022-07-01): ### 6c761d3dba23af92cba35001c852aac04ae99a5f ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ############################################# ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(9.4.18) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "parserPopUp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", ); COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt');
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $a = PopUp( ["?","degenerate", "central", "translated"], 1, ); $b = PopUp( ["?","type", "position"], 2, ); $c = PopUp( ["?","circle", "ellipse", "hyperbola", "parabola"], 4, ); $d = PopUp( ["?","circle", "ellipse", "hyperbola", "parabola"], 1, );
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML a. A [_]{$a}{5} conic can be a point, a line, a pair of lines, or no graph at all.
a. The coefficients [`D\text{,}`] [`E\text{,}`] and [`F`] determine the [_]{$b}{5} of the conic.
a. The graph is a [_]{$c}{5} if one of [`A`] or [`C`] is zero.
a. If [`A = C`] (and [`B=0`]), the graph is a [_]{$d}{5}.
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. A [$a] conic can be a point, a line, a pair of lines, or no graph at all.
a. The coefficients [`D\text{,}`] [`E\text{,}`] and [`F`] determine the [$b] of the conic.
a. The graph is a [$c] if one of [`A`] or [`C`] is zero.
a. If [`A = C`] (and [`B=0`]), the graph is a [$d].
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Evaluate ~H(t)=20 \log_{10}{\dfrac{t}{C_L}}~ for t=2\text{,} where C_L=0.5\text{.}
Answer:

The formula T = \dfrac{\log 2 \cdot t_i}{3 \log(D_f /D_0)} is used by X-ray technicians to calculate the doubling time of a malignant tumor. D_0 is the diameter of the tumor when first detected, D_f is its diameter at the next reading, and t_i is the time interval between readings, in days. Calculate the doubling time of the following tumor: its diameter when first detected was 1 cm, and 7 days later its diameter was 1.05 cm.
days

solution.p: 33 days

statement.p: The CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) provides Growth Charts for the average height and weight of children from age 2 to 20. The average height of girl children is given in centimeters by

Use the height function to complete the table.
t 2 5 10 15 20
H(t)

Between the ages of 15 and 20? cm.

webwork-reps.pg:
############################################# ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2024-04-08T17:15:45-07:00 ### A recent stable commit (2022-07-01): ### 6c761d3dba23af92cba35001c852aac04ae99a5f ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ############################################# ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(10.1.12) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "PGML.pl", "niceTables.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "contextForm.pl", "PGcourse.pl", ); COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt');
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context()->variables->add(t=>"Real"); Context()->flags->set(useBaseTenLog=>1); $f = Formula("49.29+91.3*log(t)"); @t = (2,5,10,15,20); foreach my $i (0..4) { $H[$i] = $f->eval(t=>$t[$i])->with(tolType => 'absolute', tolerance => .51,); } $h10 = $f->eval(t=>10); $h5 = $f->eval(t=>5); $d1 = $h10-$h5; $h20 = $f->eval(t=>20); $h15 = $f->eval(t=>15); $d2 = $h20-$h15; $c1 = Compute("$d1")->with(tolType => 'absolute', tolerance => .51,); $c2 = Compute("$d2")->with(tolType => 'absolute', tolerance => .51,);
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML The CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) provides Growth Charts for the average height and weight of children from age 2 to 20. The average height of girl children is given in centimeters by
[``` \begin{gathered} H(t) = 49.29+91.3 \log {t} \end{gathered} ```]
where [`t`] is in years. a. Graph the height function for [`2 \le t \le 20\text{.}`] a. Use the height function to complete the table.
[@DataTable( [ [[PGML('[`t`]'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('[`2`]'), PGML('[`5`]'), PGML('[`10`]'), PGML('[`15`]'), PGML('[`20`]'), ], [[PGML('[`H(t)`]'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('[_]{$H[0]}{3}'), PGML('[_]{$H[1]}{3}'), PGML('[_]{$H[2]}{3}'), PGML('[_]{$H[3]}{3}'), PGML('[_]{$H[4]}{3}'), ], ], align => '|*{6}{c|}', valign => 'middle', top => '3', );@]*
a. How much is a girl's height expected to increase between the ages of 5 and 10? [_]{$c1}{3} cm.
Between the ages of 15 and 20? [_]{$c2}{3} cm.
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. A graph is below. a. [@DataTable( [ [[PGML('[`t`]'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('[`2`]'), PGML('[`5`]'), PGML('[`10`]'), PGML('[`15`]'), PGML('[`20`]'), ], [[PGML('[`H(t)`]'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('[$H[0]]'), PGML('[$H[1]]'), PGML('[$H[2]]'), PGML('[$H[3]]'), PGML('[$H[4]]'), ], ], align => '|*{6}{c|}', valign => 'middle', top => '3', );@]*
a. [$c1] cm, [$c2] cm
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

a negative number or zero

.

?

a single logarithm

standard
general
exponential
point-slope
form.

logarithms
imaginary numbers

variables
powers of 10
.

?

logarithms
of the values.

negative
positive
exponent.

The opening page of Chapter 6 shows the mouse-to-elephant curve, a graph of the metabolic rate of mammals as a function of their mass. (The elephant does not appear on that graph, because its mass is too big.) The figure above shows the same function, graphed on log-log paper.
Use this graph to estimate the mass and metabolic rate for the following animals, labeled on the graph.

webwork-reps.pg:
############################################# ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2024-04-08T17:15:45-07:00 ### A recent stable commit (2022-07-01): ### 6c761d3dba23af92cba35001c852aac04ae99a5f ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ############################################# ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(10.2.5) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "PGML.pl", "niceTables.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PCCmacros.pl", "PGcourse.pl", ); COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt');
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $mouseMass = Compute("0.02")->with( tolType => 'relative', tolerance => .15, ); $mouseMR = Compute("3.5")->with( tolType => 'relative', tolerance => .15, ); $dogMass = Compute("15")->with( tolType => 'relative', tolerance => .15, ); $dogMR = Compute("500")->with( tolType => 'relative', tolerance => .15, ); $sheepMass = Compute("50")->with( tolType => 'relative', tolerance => .15, ); $sheepMR = Compute("1500")->with( tolType => 'relative', tolerance => .15, ); $cowMass = Compute("500")->with( tolType => 'relative', tolerance => .15, ); $cowMR = Compute("6000")->with( tolType => 'relative', tolerance => .15, ); $elephantMass = Compute("4000")->with( tolType => 'relative', tolerance => .15, ); $elephantMR = Compute("50000")->with( tolType => 'relative', tolerance => .15, );
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML The opening page of Chapter 6 shows the "mouse-to-elephant" curve, a graph of the metabolic rate of mammals as a function of their mass. (The elephant does not appear on that graph, because its mass is too big.) The figure above shows the same function, graphed on log-log paper.
Use this graph to estimate the mass and metabolic rate for the following animals, labeled on the graph.
>> [@DataTable( [ [[PGML('Animal'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('Mouse'), PGML('Dog'), PGML('Sheep'), ], [[PGML('Mass (kg)'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('[_]{$mouseMass}{4}'), PGML('[_]{$dogMass}{4}'), PGML('[_]{$sheepMass}{4}'), ], [[PGML('Metabolic rate (kcal/day)'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('[_]{$mouseMR}{4}'), PGML('[_]{$dogMR}{4}'), PGML('[_]{$sheepMR}{4}'), ], ], align => '|*{4}{l|}', valign => 'middle', top => '3',);@]* <<
>> [@DataTable( [ [[PGML('Animal'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('Cow'), PGML('Elephant'), ], [[PGML('Mass (kg)'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('[_]{$cowMass}{4}'), PGML('[_]{$elephantMass}{4}'), ], [[PGML('Metabolic rate (kcal/day)'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('[_]{$cowMR}{4}'), PGML('[_]{$elephantMR}{4}'), ], ], align => '|*{3}{l|}', valign => 'middle', top => '3',);@]* <<
[@KeyboardInstructions('Do not use commas. For example, use "10000" rather than "10,000".')@]**
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION >> [@DataTable( [ [[PGML('Animal'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('Mouse'), PGML('Dog'), PGML('Sheep'), PGML('Cow'), PGML('Elephant'), ], [[PGML('Mass (kg)'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('[`0.02`]'), PGML('[`15`]'), PGML('[`50`]'), PGML('[`500`]'), PGML('[`4000`]'), ], [[PGML('Metabolic rate (kcal/day)'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1',], PGML('[`3.5`]'), PGML('[`500`]'), PGML('[`1500`]'), PGML('[`6000`]'), PGML('[`50,000`]'), ], ], align => '|l|', valign => 'middle', top => '3',);@]* <<
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Solve

p.m: \blert{\text{Take the natural log of both sides.}}

statement.p: From 1994 to 1998, the number of personal computers connected to the Internet grew according to the formula N(t) = 2.8e^{0.85t}\text{,} where t = 0 in 1994 and N is in millions. (Source: Los Angeles Times, September 6, 1999)

solution.p: negative.

statement.p: A scientist isolates 25 grams of krypton-91, which decays according to the formula

where t is in seconds.
Complete the table of values showing the amount of krypton-91 left at 10-second intervals over the first minute.
t 0 10 20 30
N(t)
t 40 50 60
N(t)
Use the table to choose a suitable window and graph the function N(t)\text{.}
Write and solve an equation to answer the question: How long does it take for 60% of the krypton-91 to decay?
25e^{-0.07t}= 0.60
25e^{-0.07t}= 0.60 (25)
25e^{-0.07t}= 0.40
25e^{-0.07t}= 0.40 (25)
None of the above
Answer: t= seconds

hint.p: If 60\% of the krypton-91 has decayed, 40\% of the original 25 grams remains.

webwork-reps.pg:
############################################# ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2024-04-08T17:15:46-07:00 ### A recent stable commit (2022-07-01): ### 6c761d3dba23af92cba35001c852aac04ae99a5f ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ############################################# ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(10.3.21) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "PGML.pl", "niceTables.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "parserRadioButtons.pl", "contextForm.pl", "PGcourse.pl", ); COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt');
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context()->variables->add(t=>"Real"); $f = Formula("25*e**(-0.07*t)"); foreach my $i (0..6){ $t = 10*$i; $n[$i] = $f->eval(t=>$t)->with( tolType => 'absolute', tolerance => .0051, ); }
$explain = RadioButtons( ["\( 25e^{-0.07t}= 0.60 \)", "\( 25e^{-0.07t}= 0.60 (25) \)", "\( 25e^{-0.07t}= 0.40 \)", "\( 25e^{-0.07t}= 0.40 (25) \)", "None of the above" ], 3,); $t = Compute("ln(0.4)/(-0.07)")->with( tolType => 'absolute', tolerance => .0051, );
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML A scientist isolates [`25`] grams of krypton-91, which decays according to the formula
[```N(t) = 25e^{-0.07t}\text{,}```]
where [`t`] is in seconds. a. Complete the table of values showing the amount of krypton-91 left at [`10`]-second intervals over the first minute.
[@DataTable( [ [[PGML('[`t`]'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1', halign => 'l',], PGML('[`0`]'), PGML('[`10`]'), PGML('[`20`]'), PGML('[`30`]'), ], [[PGML('[`N(t)`]'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1', halign => 'l',], PGML('[_]{$n[0]}{3}'), PGML('[_]{$n[1]}{3}'), PGML('[_]{$n[2]}{3}'), PGML('[_]{$n[3]}{3}'), ], ], align => '|*{5}{c|}', valign => 'middle', top => '3', );@]*
[@DataTable( [ [[PGML('[`t`]'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1', halign => 'l',], PGML('[`40`]'), PGML('[`50`]'), PGML('[`60`]'), ], [[PGML('[`N(t)`]'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1', halign => 'l',], PGML('[_]{$n[4]}{3}'), PGML('[_]{$n[5]}{3}'), PGML('[_]{$n[6]}{3}'), ], ], align => '|*{4}{c|}', valign => 'middle', top => '3', );@]*
a. Use the table to choose a suitable window and graph the function [`N(t)\text{.}`]
a. Write and solve an equation to answer the question: How long does it take for 60% of the krypton-91 to decay?
[_]{$explain}{5}
Answer: [`t=`][_]{$t}{12} seconds
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT If [`60\%`] of the krypton-91 has decayed, [`40\%`] of the original [`25`] grams remains.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. [@DataTable( [ [[PGML('[`t`]'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1', halign => 'l',], PGML('[`0`]'), PGML('[`10`]'), PGML('[`20`]'), PGML('[`30`]'), PGML('[`40`]'), PGML('[`50`]'), PGML('[`60`]'), ], [[PGML('[`N(t)`]'), bottom => '1', midrule => '1', halign => 'l',], PGML('[`25`]'), PGML('[`12.41`]'), PGML('[`6.16`]'), PGML('[`3.06`]'), PGML('[`1.52`]'), PGML('[`0.75`]'), PGML('[`0.37`]'), ], ], align => '|*{8}{c|}', valign => 'middle', top => '3', );@]*
a. A graph is below.
a. [`25 e^{-0.07t} = 0.40(25)\text{;}`] [`t=\dfrac{\ln(0.4)}{-0.07}\approx 13.09 `] seconds
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Zelda invested $1000 in an account that pays 4.5% interest compounded continuously. How long will it be before the account is worth $2000?
Answer: about years.

solution.p: About 15.4 years
